page.title: 01Lavenham Gazeteer
page.content: Lavenham is a medieval village in the county of Suffolk which is world famous for its many old half-timbered buildings. It is set amidst open gently rolling countryside which is mainly devoted to cereals. Lavenham is situated on the A1141 Hadleigh to Bury St.Edmunds road,approximately 12 km NW of Hadleigh and 15 km S of Bury. Her nearest neighbour of any size is Sudbury,which is 10 km to the south. Lavenham was once the centre of the East-Anglian wool trade and became wealthy because of the high quality of its fine Broad-cloth - dyed with Lavenham woad. The decline of the woollen trade saw the introduction of rope making and sisal and jute processing which in their turn have been replaced by printing and cosmetic manufacture.Of course the main source of income is now the tourist industry .
